dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TECHNICIAN fixes a microphone on a desk. Above the desk the Presidential Seal.. We realise now we're not in a television studio, but in t Oval office of the White House..

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVE TELEVISION NEWS FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: A news ANCHOR speaks to camera..

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: The time is coming up to nine o'clock. We are expecting the President to address the nation any moment now, to announce his resignation..  10 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TECHNICIAN finishes fixing the mike on the desk. He g to his feet. Is about to go, when..

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should do this. You're a lot better looking than me. The TECHNICIAN looks up to see RICHARD NIXON, 37th Presid of the United States, standing in front of him. The TECHNICIAN beats a hasty retreat.. ‘FLASH', a picture is taken by the White House photograph

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: That’s enough now, Ollie. The other guys will only get mad if I give you too many. (looks up/strains to hear) What? OK...one more shot. NIXON poses. ‘FLASH’, another shot. NIXON squints out at television cameras, the army of TECHNICIANS. (Among them pick out NIXON's new Chief of Staff, JACK BRENNAN)...

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: You got an extra camera in case the lights go out? (another agonized smile) Standard joke. Standard joke. It’s the condemned man making jokes with his executioners ‘FLASH’, another picture is taken. NIXON spins..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: (snaps angrily) C'mon, Ollie, back off! A frightening bark. Quick temper. Savage.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: My friend Ollie always wants a lot of pictures of me. I’m afraid he’ll catch me pickin’ my nose. He wouldn’t PRINT that though, would ya, Ollie. A hint of menace. OLLIE shakes his head, terrified..

dialogues.speaker: OLLIE
dialogues.text: No, Sir.  11 12 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) -— 8/24/07 4,

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Fifteen seconds, Mr. President. MAKE UP LADIES fuss over the President, putting finishing touches to his appearance...

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: I'd like you to be generous with that powder of yours, They probably told you...I tend to...ah..perspire. A TECHNICIAN takes a light reading...

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Taking a light reading? They say blondes photograph better than brunettes. Or is it the other way around,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES RESTON JNR ~ (mid 30's) - academic, author and journalist - the long-ish hair of a liberal intellectual, being interviewed for a documentary in 1982...

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: Nowadays, people forget - but in the summer of 1972, Richard Nixon was unassailable. He was winding down the war in Vietnam, achieved a diplomatic breakthrough with the Russians, he was the first Western Leader to visit China. None of his political opponents could lay a finger on him. His approval ratings matched Kennedy‘s. He was about to be re-elected with the largest landslide in recent memory, and then...he decided to try and cover-— up a third rate burglary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STUDIO MANAGER calls out..

dialogues.speaker: STUDIO MANAGER
dialogues.text: Five, four, three.. A lighting change. NIXON turns directly to camera. In an instant his voice becomes deeper, more Presidential..  13 14 15 16 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Good evening. This is the thirty- seventh time I have spoken to you from this office where so many decisions have been made that shaped the destiny of our nation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 A MAN in his late 30's, intelligent, bespectacled, long-i hair, the faintest hint of a British Merseyside accent..( the same documentary crew)..

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: Like everyone else I had watched the Watergate drama play out in my living- room. I'd been glued to the Select and Judiciary Committee hearings night after night. Now finally, it had come to this..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON continues..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: «therefore I shall resign the Presidency effective at noon tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back tc JAMES RESTON giving his interview..

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: But instead of the satisfaction I imagined I‘d feel, I just got angrier and angrier. Because there was no admission of guilt. No apology..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: +.+.to leave office before my term is completed is abhorrent to every instinct in my body. I have never been a quitter. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 6. NIXON (cont'd) But I do so secure in the knowledge that America is a better country, and the world a safer place than when I came to power five and a half years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB ZELNICK, (40), a dark-haired, genial, measured East C academic, intellectual and political journalist..

dialogues.speaker: ZELNICK
dialogues.text: Little did I know then that I would one day be a part of the team that would try to elicit that apology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON’s resignation speech continues..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: «--to have served in this office is to have felt a very personal sense of kinship with each and every American. Tn leaving it, I do so with this prayer: may God’s grace be with you in all the day’s ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZELNICK smiles as he continues...

dialogues.speaker: ZELNICK
dialogues.text: And that the team would be led by the most unlikely white knight. A man with no political convictions. Indeed someone who had never voted in his life. But a man who had one big advantage over all of us. (a beat) He understood television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swirling lights. We're in a small, amateurish TV studio i distant Australia. A STUDIO MANAGER holds up a sign, ‘Applause’. Music plays the theme to The Frost Show, and eponymous host, (late 30’s), skips through sliding doors. Blazer and slacks. Sideburns and blow-dried hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 7.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Hello, good evening and with the eyes of the world focused on the White House, here in Australia burglars have broken into a meat factory in Brisbane and stolen a ton of pork sausages. Queensland police are looking for men in a long, thin, getaway car... The STUDIO MANAGER laughs in exaggerated fashion, leading audience...

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: My first guest tonight grew up in a tin hut in New South Wales. By the age of five she was hitting tennis balls against a wall with a piece of wood. A few weeks ago, she became the first Aboriginal Australian to win Wimbledon. She also got engaged to be married. Ladies and Gentlemen, Evonne Goolagong. Applause as the tennis player walks out to be greeted by FROST..

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: You can’t do it. We won't allow it. You cannot change your name. ‘Goolagong’ is the most famous name in Australia. Is there another reason? Something you’re not telling us? Your husband's first name isn’t ‘Ging Gang’, is it? The STUDIO MANAGER laughs in exaggerated fashion again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK BRENNAN talks to camera from his office..

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: We in the Nixon camp didn’t know much about David Frost except that he was a British talk show host with something of a playboy reputation who'd had a talk show here in the US for a while, which had won some awards but hadn‘t syndicated well, and so had been dropped by the Network...  21 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The show wraps up. Music, lights and applause. FROST is g the ‘all clear’ - then walks off stage, removing his jack A round of ‘Good show’, ‘Nice work’, as he passes TECHNIC and CAMERAMEN. FROST heads for his dressing—room.. But stops when he sees.. A CROWD of people hunched around a television monitor in production office. FROST decides to check it out. We begin to hear the familiar baritone of NIXON's voice coming from the television..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: +.-I remember my old man. He was a streetcar motorman first...then he was a farmer..then he had a lemon ranch.. FROST reaches the crowd, which parts. FROST pushes throug see the television, where NIXON speaks. The former Presid stands on a raised stage, surrounded by his family..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ..it was the poorest lemon ranch in California. He sold it before they found oil on it.. FROST shoots a look at his DIRECTOR..

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Nixon. Saying farewell to the White House staff.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: And nobody will ever write a book about my mother. But my mother was a saint,

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: What? This is live?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Yes. FROST stares at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: What time is it in Washington?  22 23 24 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 9.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: (checks watch) Nine am.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Why didn't he wait? It's six in the morning on the West Coast. Half his audience is still asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON is fighting emotion as he addresses a room full of White House Staff, security service, family members, including PAT NIXON...

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: »-and so, IT say to all of you, be proud of what you have done. Continue to give your best. Never get discouraged. Never be petty. The atmosphere is electric. We pick out a granite-faced BRENNAN among emotional STAFFERS that are openly weeping.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Always remember. Others may hate you, but those who hate you don’t win unless you hate them, and then you destroy yourself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST stares at the TV as NIXON walks towards a waiting helicopter on the White House lawn...

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Find out the numbers for this, will you? Worldwide. ON TV: NIXON turns and gives his victory salute..

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Sure. I’ll get someone onto it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The helicopter lifts away from the White House..  25 26 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside: the helicopter is sound-proofed, and luxuriously equipped, in beige corduroy, with telephones and armchair with the Presidential Seal. More like a private jet. NIXON, a painful silhouette, stares out of the window, watches the White House become smaller and smaller, disappearing.. COL. JACK BRENNAN, (45), NIXON’s Chief-of Staff, dark-hai thick-set, ex-military, athletic, not PAT NIXON, sits opposite the PRESIDENT..

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: It’s a travesty, Sir. NIXON stares out of the window..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Well, it’s done now. And this time there’s no coming back.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Never say never, Mr. President. What you need first is rest. Then who knows? Anything can happen.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: No, Jack. Not this time. NIXON’s eyes stare out of the window..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: This time it’s over. BRENNAN stares at NIXON..

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I remember his face. Just ravaged with pain. Staring out of the window... INT. BRENNAN‘S OFFICE - SAN CLEMENTE ~ (1982) 26 BRENNAN tries to contain his anger..

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: ++-while down below him, liberal America cheered! And gloated! The trendies! The hippies! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 BRENNAN (cont'd) The draft-dodgers and dilettantes! They had got rid of Richard Nixon. Their bogeyman. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 10A.
dialogues.text: 27 28 29 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 11. BRENNAN (cont'd) And who did they get in his place? (a beat) Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LWT studios, a tall building in the heart of London, on t south bank of the Thames..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hard-hitting current affairs programme, ‘Weekend World’ finishes taping. It‘s confrontational. Uncompromising.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Minister. Next week’s programme comes from Bournemouth and the start of the Labour Party Conference. Until then, goodbye. The show finishes. It’s producer, JOHN BIRT, longish hair spectacles, walks out onto the studio floor, takes the PRESENTER aside, and gives notes.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: What are you doing? You had your foot on his throat and you let him go!

dialogues.speaker: PRESENTER
dialogues.text: (gestures ear) I had the mike in. You didn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t need to say anything. He broke the law. You should have finished him off! An ASSISTANT brings over a phone. Hands it to BIRT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Frost for you.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: Hello? David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID FROST sits in the back of his Bentley. He has overh BIRT giving the notes. He chuckles..  FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Beat them, John! Beat them with a stick! God knows I still bear my own scars. Now, where do you fancy for lunch? Simpsons or The Caprice? I’ve booked both. 11A.  30 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) ~ 8/24/07 12.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I've only got half an hour. It'll have to be the canteen here at the studios. FROST’s smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: The canteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST’s eyes widen in horror as he and BIRT enter the che smoke-filled, subsidized canteen of a major studio comple Filled with technicians, crew members, etc.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: So what's so important that it couldn’t wait. That it HAD to be today. The two men take trays, and start drifting along the line

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: I've had an idea, John. Rather a bold idea. For an interview. And in a moment of....well, it's too late now... it‘s done...I called his people and made an offer. Now...if the subject were to say ‘yes’, well, he’s rather a big fish, that swims in not untricky waters...so it goes without saying, I‘d want a dear friend and the finest producer I know by my side.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Richard Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: Richard Nixon!

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Don‘t look like that.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: How do you expect me to look? I spent yesterday evening watching you interview the Bee Gees.  31 32 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 13.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Weren’t they terrific?

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: So...what kind of interview?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: A full, extensive look back over his life. His Presidency.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: And. .?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: And what..?

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: C'mon, David, surely the only thing that would interest anyone about Richard Nixon would be a full, no holds-barred confession.. FROST gestures...

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Oh, we'll get that, too.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: From Richard Nixon?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: C'mon, John, just think of the numbers it would get. Do you know how many people watched his farewell speech in the White House? Four hundred million? INT. LWT STUDIOS - BIRT’S OFFICE - DAY - (1982) 31 BIRT smiles as he remembers...

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: But in the end, we heard nothing. Soon after arriving in California, Nixon was rushed to hospital with an acute attack of phlebitis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Crash”, NIXON, (on a gurney), is rushed into hospital through swing doors. Raised voices.  33 34 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 14. DOCTORS, NURSES and SECRET SERVICE surround the gurney..

dialogues.speaker: BIRT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was around this time that the new President, Gerald Ford, desperate to move the agenda on from Watergate gave Nixon a full, free and absolute pardon..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIXON is attached to drips, post-operation, unconscious. His WIFE and DAUGHTERS, along with two NURSES keep vigil his bedside. Monitors beep. SECRET SERVICE MEN keep guard outside his room. It has the atmosphere of a wake. OVER T a voice..

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ++I have searched my conscience to determine the right thing to do with respect to Richard Nixon, and his loyal wife and family. Images on TV of White House staffers HALDEMAN, EHRLICHMAN DEAN, COLSON etc going to jail for their role in Watergat

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Theirs is an American tragedy in which we have all played a part...

dialogues.speaker: ZELNICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It meant the man who had committed the biggest felony in American political history would never stand trial. INT. NURSES’ STATION - HOSPITAL - DAY - (1974) 34 At the NURSES’ station, a television plays Gerald Ford's pardon speech. No one pays much attention. They carry on going about their business...

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: +,+-therefore I, Gerald Ford, President of the United States, pursuant to the pardon power conferred upon me by Article II, Section 2 of the Constitution...  35 36 37 38 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 15.

dialogues.speaker: BELNICK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That week the mood among those of us around the world that believed America still had a healthy democratic tradition was pretty bleak.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVE TELEVISION NEWS FOOTAGE 35
dialogues.text: Images of civil protest, US citizens outraged by Ford’s pardon, taking to the streets. A country torn apart..

dialogues.speaker: FORD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: +..do grant a full, free and absolute pardon unto Richard Nixon for all the offences which he has committed against the United States.. INT. DAVID FROST’S LONDON HOME - NIGHT - (1974) 36 FROST is on the phone, working from home. He catches the images of civil protest on his television in London. We CLOSE on FROST’s face. As he watches the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dusk. A beautiful sunset. Above the beach, beside a coast guard station, a traditional Spanish-style house. This is CASA PACIFICA. At the foot of the garden, NIXON sits in a wheelchair. Alone. Recuperating. Wounded. In silhouette. Staring out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: INT. NIXON’S OFFICE - DAY - (1975) 38 NIXON is in a wheelchair, his left leg stretched out, is his study working on his memoirs with FRANK GANNON and DI SAWYER. A knock at the door. NIXON’s valet, MANOLO SANCHE clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: MANOLO
dialogues.text: Mr. President? Swifty Lazar is here. GANNON and SAWYER get to their feet to go..  39 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 16.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: No, no. Stay! You'll get a kick out of this. My literary agent. From “Hollywood”. Hygiene obsessive. SWIFTY LAZAR, barely five feet tall, immaculately dressed tailored clothes, appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Mr. President, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Irving Lazar, Diane Sawyer, Frank Gannon.. A round of handshakes and greetings. FRANK GANNON notices SWIFTY wiping his hands after each handshake...

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: I was about to tell my associates how you got your nickname “Swifty”.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Did three deals for Humphrey Bogart in one afternoon. When he wasn’t even my client. GANNON and SAWYER laugh, then leave. EXT. CASA PACIFICA — DAY 39 SWIFTY and NIXON move towards the pergola. MANOLO SANCHEZ wheeling the former President down the path..

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: So how are you feeling, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Better. Though not yet well enough to ‘golf’, thank God. I despise that game. Never retire, Mr. Lazar. To me the unhappiest people of the world are those in the watering places, South of France, Palm Springs, Palm Beach, Newport..going to parties every night, playing golf every afternoon, then drinking too much, talking too much, thinking too little, retired - no purpose. What makes life mean something is purpose. A goal. The battle. The struggle. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 17. NIXON (cont'd) Even if you don’t win it. You know, when my doctor declared me unfit to give testimony in the Watergate trial everyone thought I‘d be relieved. They were wrong. That was the lowest I got.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Well, if it‘s a challenge you want, here’s one you might enjoy. How to spend two million dollars...$2.3 to be precise. It's what I got for your memoirs.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Which might be a little short of what I wanted, but let me assure you, it’s a_whole lot more than they wanted.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: That book we're working on is important to me. It‘s probably the only chance I’m going to get to put the record straight and remind people the Nixon years weren't ALL bad..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWIFTY and NIXON eating lunch on the Presidential china..

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: You know, if you want to put the record straight, I’d at least talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: David Frost. The English talk-show guy. NIXON looks up. Bemused..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Why would I want to talk to David Frost?  41 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 18.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: A while back he wrote asking for an interview. We didn‘t get back. Frankly, we didn’t find him ‘appropriate’. But if you want to get your side of the story across, he'd be the guy who’d let you.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: I thought we were doing one with CBS?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: We are. I just figured doing it with Frost would be a lot easier than doing it with Mike Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: It would. It would also have less credibility.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: True. But we could probably get better money. NIXON looks up. Now he‘s interested.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Look, we will always have three-fifty on the table from CBS. But if I can get Frost to pay more, and secure better terms it might be shame to pass. Be interesting to know where he is right now..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sydney Opera House in the background. FROST, in blaze and tie, watches ag a man who’s hands and feet are tied i lowered into the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: We tied him to railway tracks, and he escaped! We buried him alive, and he walked free! Today we are lowering escape artist Derek Harrison into the water - to see if he can miraculously cheat death once more! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 18a, FROST (cont'd) Good evening, and welcome to “Great Escapes”, my name is David Frost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 43 FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 19. All around FROST, a TV CREW. Among them, an attractive bl PRODUCTION ASSISTANT in a red beret...

dialogues.speaker: INT, SWIFTY'S HOME
dialogues.text: SWIFTY LAZAR sits in his Los Angeles home. Palm trees and sunshine. He speaks to the documentary crew...

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: In any deal, you need to know your opponent’s breaking point. And to assess that you might call late at night, or at the week-end. If they take the call, it means they’re desperate, and from that moment on, you know you've got the upper hand..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Rrrring”, the phone rings. FROST hits the light. He answ the phone, his face creased with sleep. (We notice a slee female figure beside him. A shock of blonde hair. A red b at the foot of the bed).

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Mr. Frost? Irving Lazar.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: “Swifty” Lazar? I represent President Nixon. The GIRL sits up in his bed..

dialogues.speaker: BERET GIRL
dialogues.text: What time is it..?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Bad time?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: No! Not at all..  FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 194.

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: I'm calling with regard to your request for an interview. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) — 8/24/07 SWIFTY (cont'd) And to say, having considered it, my client is not necessarily opposed to the idea.

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Really? That's terrific news. 44 INT. SWIFTY’S OFFICE - DAY - (1975) SWIFTY speaks on the phone with NIXON..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: Mr. President, it’s half a million dollars. For a news interview. It’s unprecedented.

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: And the catch?

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY
dialogues.text: With Frost? None. It'll be a biiiig wet kiss. A ‘valentine’. This guy is so grateful to be getting it at all, he’ll pitch puff-balls all night and pay half a million dollars for the privilege. A silence. Then..

dialogues.speaker: NIXON
dialogues.text: You think you could get $550,000? 45 INT. SWIFTY’S HOLLYWOOD HOME - DAY - (1982) SWIFTY in his home. He talks to the documentary crew..

dialogues.speaker: SWIFTY

dialogues.text: London. The busiest airport in the world. To establish.

dialogues.text: JOHN BIRT and DAVID FROST come in through revolving doors and walk through the airport terminal..

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: How could you have done that?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: What? Everywhere they go, heads turn. FROST is clearly a major celebrity in his native country.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: $600,000. It‘s a fortune, David. Two hundred on signature?

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the money. They reach the check-in desk, hand over their passports. STEWARDESS blushes as FROST smiles at her..

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: Most Americans think he belongs in jail. You’re making him a rich man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIRT and FROST walk effortlessly through non-existent air security, (oh, for the 1970's)...

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: Plus, by outbidding them, you’ve made enemies of the Networks...

dialogues.speaker: FROST
dialogues.text: They're just jealous.

dialogues.speaker: BIRT
dialogues.text: ».who are already sounding off about cheque-book journalism. If the Networks are against you, syndication is always going to be a struggle. No syndication, no advance sales. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROST/NIXON (Yellow Revs) - 8/24/07 21a. BIRT (cont'd) No advance sales, no commercials. No commercials, no revenue..
